Mumbai: Drunk man outside railway loo wo.description: MUMBAI: A 28-year-old man dragged a uniformed railway constable towards the railway tracks at GTB Nagar station and threatened to throw him in front of a running train around midnight on Saturday. The accused, Murugesh Devendra, was furious after the cop pulled him up for blocking access to a public toilet at the station. When reinforcements were called in, Devendra tried to flee but the cops nabbed him. “Devendra has been booked for assaulting a public servant and for intimidation,” said senior inspector Rajendra Pal, Wadala GRP. Constable Omprakash Munde, 27, was on night duty on Saturday. Around 12.05am, the operator of a public toilet on platform 1-2 told Munde about a man lying sprawled at the entrance to the toilet. Munde went to the man (Devendra) and woke him up. Devendra, who was sloshed, had collapsed in front of the toilet. Angry at being woken up, he hurled abuses at Munde. Expecting him to get violent, Munde called up his colleague, Shende, for help. Shende, who was on duty at Chunabhatti station, reached GTB Nagar. Meanwhile, Devendra ran towards Munde and started hitting him, leading to a scuffle between the two. According to the FIR, Devendra started to drag Munde towards the tracks and said he was going to “push the cop on the tracks, in front of a running train, and kill him”. By then, Shende reached the spot and found the two grappling. Shende rushed to his colleague’s aid. “By then, Devendra realised he was going to get caught. He bit Munde’s fingers and jumped onto the space between two sets of tracks in order to flee. Munde and Shende followed him on the tracks and managed to nab him,” said Pal. Devendra was brought to Wadala railway police chowky and arrested. Munde was sent for a medical check-up. The police said Devendra does odd jobs and lives in Mankhurd. He was travelling ticketless when he was caught and the police may apply charges relevant under the Railways Act. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Urmila Matondkar.description: MUMBAI: The Congress on Friday nominated actress Urmila Matondkar and former Lok Sabha speaker Meira Kumar from Mumbai North and Bihar's Sasaram parliamentary constituencies respectively. The party renominated its sitting MP Ranjet Ranjan from Supaul in Bihar, as it released a list of another 12 candidates for the general elections. With this list, the Congress has so far nominated 305 Lok Sabha candidates. Urmila Matondkar to contest from Mumbai North parliamentary constituency on a Congress ticket.… https://t.co/JweKWNh1FN— ANI (@ANI) 1553836382000It also changed its candidate in Uttar Pradesh's Maharajganj by now fielding Supriya Shrinate in place of Tanushree Tripathi, the daughter of jailed politician Amarmani Tripathi, after facing widespread criticism. "The Congress central election committee has approved the candidature of Urmila Matondkar as party candidate to contest the ensuing general elections from Mumbai North parliamentary constituency in Maharashtra," a party statement said. Matondkar had joined the Congress after meeting Rahul Gandhi on Wednesday and had later said that she was "here to stay". Meira Kumar have been contesting from her Sasaram parliamentary constituency for many years but had lost in the 2014 Lok Sabha polls. Apart from Supriya Shrinate, in the list of 12 candidates released by the party, four are from Bihar and seven from Odisha. The Congress also released a list of 20 candidates for Odisha Assembly election. Sikh beaten in Delhi.description: NEW DELHI: There was high drama in north Delhi's Mukherjee Nagar on Sunday evening when a group of policemen clashed with a Gramin Sewa driver and his son, a minor. The incident was captured by passersby on mobile phone and the footage went viral. In the video, a few policemen were seen hitting the driver with sticks and then kicking him. The man was later detained. However, Delhi Police, in a statement, claimed that the incident took place after the driver hit a police van and started arguing with cops. Things took a turn for the worse as the driver then allegedly pulled out a sword and assaulted an on-duty officer. While trying to escape from the spot, the accused hit another cop with his vehicle, police said. Later, the policemen chased the vehicle and forced the driver to stop. The juvenile son of the driver also joined the argument, they said. In another video of the incident, the driver was seen arguing with a cop while holding a sword. An inquiry has been initiated into the incident. Meanwhile, five people, including two women, were arrested for assaulting cops who tried to intervene in a fight near Tibia college in central Delhi. The incident happened on Friday evening. CCTV footage was being checked to ascertain the exact sequence of events, police said. PM Modi.description: JEYPORE: Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Friday said his government had taken measures to set up a 'chowkidar' in space and asked people to vote for a government that can take concrete decisions and not just raise slogans. Launching his campaign in eastern India with a rally in Jeypore area of Odisha's Koraput district, the prime minister said the NDA government wouldn't have been able to do any development work in the country without the support of the people. He sought blessings from his supporters for the 2019 Lok Sabha elections and asserted that the NDA government has left no stone unturned to bring about development in the state. Land, air or space, we had courage to do surgical strikes: PM Modi"The NDA government has been working hard to develop road and rail infrastructure in the state. There is no dearth of funds when it comes to development work in the country. "In the last five years, the government has been able to build homes for eight lakh families, light up 3,000 houses and provide gas connections to 40 lakh homes," Modi stated. Referring to Mission Shakti, when India demonstrated anti-satellite (ASAT) missile capability by shooting down a live satellite, he said the government has taken measures to set up a 'chowkidar' (watchman) in space. He came down heavily on opposition parties who he said "belittled" the space achievement. "Those that are criticising the anti-satellite technology will be given a befitting reply in the elections," he claimed, urging people to vote for a government that can take concrete decisions, not the one that only raises slogans.
